choices.text: Lateral part of the medial femoral condyle
Medial part of the lateral femoral condyle
Lateral part of the lateral femoral condyle
Medial part of the medial femoral condyle

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with knee pain and occasional joint locking. MRI reveals a lesion on the posterolateral aspect of the medial femoral condyle. The Wilson test is positive. What is the most likely diagnosis site in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common site of osteochondritis dissecans is the lateral aspect of the medial femoral condyle.

  • Osteochondritis dissecans (OCD) involves avascular necrosis of subchondral bone and its overlying cartilage.
  • It typically affects adolescents between 10-15 years, especially males with active sports history.
  • Most common joints involved: Knee > Ankle > Elbow
  • Most common site in the knee: Posterolateral aspect of the medial femoral condyle
  • Clinical signs: Intermittent knee pain, swelling, joint effusion, mechanical locking
  • Wilson's test: Positive-pain elicited on internal rotation of the tibia with extension
  • Investigation of choice: MRI
  • Management:
    • Undisplaced lesion: Conservative with immobilisation
    • Displaced lesion: Removal + Osteochondral autograft transfer system (OATS)

Key Takeaway:

Osteochondritis dissecans commonly affects the lateral aspect of the medial femoral condyle and presents with knee pain, locking, and a positive Wilson test.

choices.text: The Knee is the most common joint to be involved
May require knee replacement in severe cases

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy complains of knee pain and occasional joint locking. Wilson's test is positive. MRI suggests a lesion over the posterolateral aspect of the medial femoral condyle. Which of the following statements is not true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation: Knee replacement is not indicated in osteochondritis dissecans even in severe stages.

  • Osteochondritis dissecans (OCD) involves avascular necrosis of subchondral bone and its overlying cartilage.
  • Most commonly affected joint: Knee (especially the posterolateral part of the medial femoral condyle)
  • Typically seen in boys aged 10-15 years with a history of repetitive microtrauma or sports.
  • Clinical presentation: Knee pain, effusion, locking due to intra-articular loose bodies.
  • Wilson's test: Positive in cases with medial femoral condyle involvement.
  • MRI: Investigation of choice
  • Treatment:
    • Undisplaced lesions: Conservative management (cast, activity modification)
    • Displaced lesions: Removal of loose bodies + Osteochondral Autograft Transfer System (OATS)
  • Knee replacement is not a treatment option even in the late stages of OCD.

Explanation of other options:

Knee is the most common joint (Option A): Correct-OCD primarily affects the knee.

It can cause loose bodies (Option B): Correct-detachment of necrosed fragment forms intra-articular loose bodies.

Wilson's sign can be positive (Option C): Correct-elicits pain during internal rotation and extension of the tibia.

Key Takeaway:

OCD is a pediatric joint condition affecting the medial femoral condyle with conservative or surgical management; knee replacement is not a standard treatment.

choices.text: Stress fracture neck of the femur

questions.text: A 24-year-old male, a regular gym-goer, presents with left hip pain aggravated during squats and lunges. Examination reveals restricted hip abduction and internal rotation. He admits to chronic anabolic steroid use. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chronic steroid use and restricted hip movement in a young male are strongly suggestive of avascular necrosis of the femoral head.

  • Avascular necrosis (AVN) of the femoral head involves bone ischemia leading to structural collapse.
  • The most common non-traumatic cause is steroid use, followed by alcohol abuse.
  • Other risk factors: Trauma, sickle cell disease, Caisson's disease, Gaucher's disease, thrombophilia, and antiretrovirals.
  • Clinical features: Groin or hip pain, limp, restricted abduction and internal rotation, positive sectoral sign.
  • X-ray (late): Crescent sign indicates subchondral collapse.
  • MRI: Investigation of choice (detects early marrow changes).
  • Treatment:
    • Early stage: Core decompression ± stem cell therapy
    • Advanced collapse: Total hip arthroplasty (THA)

Explanation of other options:

Stress fracture neck of femur (Option A): Presents with night pain or during activity; steroids increase risk, but typically has point tenderness and not internal rotation restriction.

Osteomalacia (Option C): Presents with diffuse bone pain, proximal muscle weakness, and Looser's zones-not focal joint restriction.

Femoroacetabular impingement (Option D): May mimic AVN but occurs without collapse; not associated with steroid use.

Key Takeaway:

Steroid use with restriction of hip internal rotation and abduction should raise suspicion for AVN of the femoral head.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male treated with corticosteroids for pemphigus presents with dull aching pain in the groin. His X-ray is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The X-ray shows the classical crescent sign in the femoral head, diagnostic of avascular necrosis.

  • AVN (Avascular Necrosis) refers to ischemic death of bone tissue leading to subchondral collapse and joint dysfunction.
  • The crescent sign is a radiolucent subchondral line indicating bone collapse without articular surface breach-hallmark of AVN.
  • Steroid use, particularly in autoimmune conditions like pemphigus, is a strong risk factor.
  • Other causes: trauma, alcohol abuse, antiretrovirals, sickle cell disease, Gaucher's disease, decompression sickness, thrombophilias.
  • Clinical features: Groin pain, restricted hip abduction and internal rotation, positive sectoral sign.
  • Investigation of choice: MRI (detects early AVN before X-ray changes).
  • Treatment:
    • Early stages: Core decompression ± bone marrow grafting
    • Late stages (collapse/arthritis): Total hip replacement (THR)

Explanation of other options:

Septic arthritis (Option B): Presents with acute fever, systemic signs, and intense joint pain-not gradual onset or crescent sign.

Synovitis (Option C): No structural bony changes seen on X-ray; usually soft tissue swelling only.

Osteoarthritis (Option D): Characterised by joint space narrowing, subchondral sclerosis, and osteophytes-not crescent sign.

Key Takeaway:

A crescent sign on X-ray with steroid use and hip pain is diagnostic of AVN of the femoral head.

questions.text: 18 year old sickle cell anaemia patient presents with pain in both hips for 6 months. O/E, there is restriction of abduction and internal rotation of both hips. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hip pain with restricted abduction and internal rotation in a sickle cell patient strongly suggests avascular necrosis of the femoral head.

  • Sickle cell disease is a well-known risk factor for AVN due to recurrent microvascular occlusion.
  • Limitation of abduction and internal rotation is a typical examination finding.
  • MRI is the investigation of choice; X-ray shows crescent sign in later stages.
  • Treatment depends on the stage: core decompression in early stages, THR in advanced disease.

Explanation of other options:

Salmonella osteomyelitis (Option A): Common in sickle cell but affects long bones; doesn't cause bilateral hip stiffness.

Septic arthritis (Option C): Presents acutely with fever, monoarticular involvement, and intense pain, not chronic bilateral symptoms.

Coxa vara (Option D): Congenital/developmental condition with altered neck-shaft angle, not linked with systemic hemoglobinopathy.

Key Takeaway:

Bilateral hip pain with restricted internal rotation in sickle cell anaemia should raise high suspicion for AVN.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for AVN of the femoral head?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hypothyroidism is not associated with AVN, unlike the other options, which are known haematological or pharmacologic risk factors.

  • Avascular necrosis (AVN) of the femoral head results from compromised blood suppl,y leading to bone death and joint collapse.
  • Common risk factors include:
    • Steroid usage
    • Sickle cell disease
    • Protein C and S deficiency
    • Trauma
    • Alcoholism
    • Antiretrovirals
    • Gaucher's disease
    • Caisson's disease
  • Hypothyroidism is not implicated as a risk factor in AVN pathogenesis.
  • Clinical clue: hip pain, restricted abduction & internal rotation.
  • MRI is the most sensitive investigation; the crescent sign may be seen on delayed X-ray.
  • Treatment:
    • Early stage - core decompression
    • Late stage - total hip replacement (THR)

Explanation of other options:

Protein C deficiency (Option A): Causes thrombophilia, a recognised AVN risk.

Sickle cell anaemia (Option B): Repeated vaso-occlusion leads to AVN.

Steroid usage (Option C): Strongly associated with AVN, especially in high-dose/prolonged therapy.

Key Takeaway:

Always exclude systemic and hematologic causes in AVN; hypothyroidism is not among them.

questions.text: Traumatic AVN of the Neck of the femur occurs due to injury to which vessels?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lateral retinacular branch of the medial circumflex femoral artery is the main vascular supply to the femoral head and is commonly disrupted in femoral neck fractures.

  • The medial circumflex femoral artery (MCFA) is the principal vessel supplying the femoral head.
  • It forms an extracapsular arterial ring at the base of the femoral neck, from which retinacular branches ascend.
  • Among these, the lateral retinacular branch of the MCFA is the most important, providing the majority of blood to the femoral head.
  • These are end arteries, so any disruption (as in fracture neck of femur) can lead to AVN.
  • The ligamentum teres artery plays only a minor role in adults.

Explanation of other options:

Lateral retinacular branch of LCFA (Option B): Contributes minimally to femoral head blood supply.

Medial retinacular branch of MCFA (Option C): Less dominant than the lateral branch.

Medial retinacular branch of LCFA (Option D): Not involved in supplying the femoral head.

Key Takeaway:

In traumatic AVN of the femoral head, always suspect disruption of the lateral retinacular branch of the MCFA.

questions.text: A Fracture not associated with AVN is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The proximal tibia has a good cancellous blood supply and is not typically associated with AVN.

  • Avascular necrosis occurs in bones with poor collateral circulation or end-arterial blood supply.
  • Neck of femur(Option A ruled out): Supplied by retinacular arteries-fracture leads to high AVN risk.
  • Neck of talus(Option B ruled out): AVN risk due to tenuous vascular supply (via artery of tarsal canal).
  • Waist of scaphoid(Option D ruled out): Retrograde blood supply predisposes the proximal pole to AVN.
  • Proximal tibia: Cancellous bone with rich vascularity-AVN is rare.

Key Takeaway:

Fractures involving areas with poor vascular supply are at higher risk of AVN; the proximal tibia is not among them.

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for Keinbock's disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Negative ulnar variance predisposes the lunate to avascular necrosis, termed Kienb'ck's disease.

  • Kienböck's disease is avascular necrosis (AVN) of the lunate bone, leading to collapse and carpal instability.
  • It commonly affects young adults and manual laborers.
  • Negative ulnar variance: The ulna is shorter than the radius, leading to increased axial load on the lunate, contributing to vascular compromise.
  • Risk factors include:
    • Negative ulnar variance
    • Repetitive microtrauma
    • Anatomical variants like single-vessel blood supply
  • Clinical signs: Dorsal wrist pain, reduced grip strength, and limited wrist motion.
  • Radiology: Lunate sclerosis, collapse, fragmentation.
  • Advanced stages may show carpal collapse or arthritis.
  • Treatment varies from immobilization to radial shortening osteotomy or proximal row carpectomy.

Explanation of other options:

Positive ulnar variance (Option A): Increases load on the TFCC and ulna-not a risk factor for lunate AVN.

Positive radial variance (Option C): Not a recognized anatomical variant; not associated with lunate AVN.

Negative radial variance (Option D): Term not clinically relevant-focus is on ulnar variance.

Key Takeaway:

Negative ulnar variance is a key anatomical risk factor for developing Kienböck's disease.

questions.text: A 25-year-old manual worker presents with chronic dorsal wrist pain. Radiographs show increased sclerosis and collapse of a central carpal bone. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Kienböck's disease is avascular necrosis (AVN) of the lunate bone.

  • Kienböck's disease involves osteonecrosis of the lunate, typically presenting with chronic wrist pain and stiffness.
  • Most commonly affects dominant hand of men aged 20-40 years.
  • Imaging may reveal sclerosis, fragmentation, and collapse of the lunate.
  • Key risk factor: Negative ulnar variance (ulna shorter than radius).
  • Other risk factors: repetitive trauma, vascular insufficiency.
  • Complications include radiocarpal arthritis and wrist instability in advanced stages.
  • Treatment ranges from immobilization (early) to radial shortening or proximal row carpectomy (late).

Explanation of other options:

AVN of talus (Option A): Seen in talar neck fractures, not linked to Kienböck's.

AVN of scaphoid (Option B): Known as Preiser’s disease.

AVN of capitate (Option C): Extremely rare, not Kienböck's.

Key Takeaway:

Kienböck's disease is defined as AVN of the lunate and should be suspected in young adults with dorsal wrist pain and lunate sclerosis.

choices.text: Involves osteochondritis of the ring epiphysis

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with progressive kyphosis and back pain. Imaging reveals wedge-shaped vertebrae in the thoracic spine. Which of the following statements is not true about his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Scheuermann's disease leads to kyphotic deformity, not scoliosis.

  • Scheuermann's kyphosis is a structural kyphotic deformity occurring during adolescence.(Option B ruled out)
  • It is due to osteochondritis of the ring epiphysis of thoracic vertebrae.(Option D ruled out)
  • Typically affects adolescent boys aged 13-17 years.(Option A ruled out)
  • Presents with pain, postural deformity, and thoracic kyphosis with anterior vertebral wedging.
  • Scoliosis is not a primary feature, though mild compensatory curvature may occur.
  • Diagnosis: X-ray shows ≥3 contiguous vertebrae with >5° wedging.
  • Treatment depends on curve severity: observation, bracing, or surgery.

Explanation of other options:

Usually affects adolescent boys (Option A): True; most common in male teens.

Causes kyphotic deformity (Option B): True; hallmark of the disease.

Involves osteochondritis of the ring epiphysis (Option D): True; key pathological basis.

Key Takeaway:

Scheuermann's disease causes kyphosis due to vertebral epiphyseal osteochondritis but does not primarily cause scoliosis.

choices.text: Inflammation of lower pole of patella

questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is the list of common named avascular necrosis and osteochondritis of bones.

choices.text: More common in males than females
Core decompression is a method of treatment
Steroid intake is associated with bilateral AVN

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding avascular necrosis (AVN) of the femoral head?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Wilson's test is specific to osteochondritis dissecans and is not associated with AVN of the femoral head.

  • AVN of the femoral head results from disruption of blood supply, leading to ischemia, collapse, and secondary osteoarthritis.
  • It is more common in males, particularly in the 3rd-5th decades.(Option A ruled out)
  • Core decompression is used in early stages to relieve pressure and restore perfusion.(Option B ruled out)
  • Steroid usage is a major risk factor, especially for bilateral AVN.(Option D ruled out)
  • Wilson's test is not applicable in AVN; it is used to evaluate osteochondritis dissecans of the knee.

Key Takeaway:

Wilson's test is a clinical sign seen in osteochondritis dissecans, not AVN of the femoral head.
